position.marginalia_text: Semper pueri, qui imparati, cum res vocat.

marginalia.translation: They who are unprepared when the matter calls will always be boys.

position.marginalia_text: Euerie mans skill in his owne Horizon.
Bias semper paratus: quia Omnia Sua secum.

marginalia.translation: Bias of Priene was always prepared: because all his things were with him.

position.marginalia_text: Apollonius semper paratus: quia pansophus, et in se totus. Ars, et Virtus, nunq[uam] imparata[e].

marginalia.translation: Apollonius of Tyana was always prepared because he was pansophist, and every part was in him. Art and virtue are never unprepared.

position.marginalia_text: Quicq[ui]d est in deo, est deus. Quicqud in viro, vir. Apostoli nullo secum Libro
egebant, aut instrumento. Spiritus supplebat omnia. diuini viri.

marginalia.translation: Whatever is in God, is God. Whatever is in man, is man. The apostles did not need any books or instruments with them. The Spirit supplied all. Divine men.

position.marginalia_text: Romani semper parati: quià viri animo, et corpore; et seria virtute pra[e]diti. Apostoli semper parati: quia fide, et spe pleni; à solo Deo pendebant, et Seipsis. Stoici semper parati: quia toti in se, et ex se; nullis egebant externis.

marginalia.translation: The Romans were always prepared because they were men in mind and body; and they were gifted with serious virtue. The apostles were always prepared because they were full of faith and hope; they depended only on God and themselves. The Stoics were always prepared because they were whole in themselves and from themselves; they did not lack any external things.
